questions.text: A 62-year-old man with diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia comes to the emergency department of medical center with chest pain, nausea, vomiting, and diaphoresis. An electrocardiogram demonstrates ST elevation in the anterior leads, and cardiac enzymes are markedly elevated. Investigators at the center are designing a randomized control trial to test the hypothesis that drug B will decrease the mortality associated with acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction compared to standard of care. To ensure that investigators will not miss a difference between drug B and standard of care (if a difference truly exists), which of the following would they want to maximize?
questions.solution: Ans. D) ﻿﻿﻿1-beta

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the defibrillator showed the following. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 mg epinephrine IV 

 

Pulseless patient with asystole or PEA → non-shockable rhythm.

 

Immediate steps:

 

  1. Continue high-quality CPR.
  2. IV/IO access.
  3. Administer epinephrine 1 mg IV/IO every 3–5 minutes.

 

Defibrillation or synchronized cardioversion is not indicated for non-shockable rhythms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Defibrillation: Only indicated for ventricular fibrillation (VF) or pulseless ventricular tachycardia (pVT).

 

Option B. Synchronized cardioversion: Used for hemodynamically unstable VT with pulse or supraventricular tachycardia, not pulseless rhythms.

 

Option D. 0.5 mg atropine IV: No longer recommended in asystole or PEA per current ACLS guidelines.

choices.text: Knowledge and skills instilled in the minds

questions.text: All of the following apply to health propaganda except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reflective behavior is promoted

 

Propaganda is designed to persuade and often targets emotions and attitudes using selective information; it focuses on dissemination and persuasive messaging rather than fostering critical, reflective decision-making. Therefore promoting reflective (critical) behavior is not a typical aim of propaganda.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knowledge and skills instilled in the minds: Propaganda may convey knowledge or instructions, but often in a biased manner; it can instill actionable skills if designed that way.

 

Option C. Appeals to emotion: A hallmark of propaganda is emotional appeal to influence attitudes and behaviour quickly.

 

Option D. Process is information centered: Propaganda often centres on targeted information (though selective), which drives its messaging strategy.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD due to blisters on his trunk and groin. Itching has occurred for the past several weeks, and blisters developed a week ago. He has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. The patient received the zoster vaccine at age 60. Examination shows numerous 0.5- to 3-cm bullous skin lesions. The findings from a skin biopsy are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

  • Venturi masks deliver precise fixed concentrations of oxygen using different color-coded adapters.
  •  Mechanism: The Venturi adapter entrains room air in a controlled ratio to oxygen flow, allowing accurate FiO₂ delivery, especially useful in COPD patients.

questions.text: A child was brought to a pediatrician with tense blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema. Immunofluorescence of the biopsy specimen is shown below. What is the first-line drug used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Dapsone

questions.text: Match the following scientists with their discoveries:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d 

 

  • 1-b. Walter Reed – Yellow fever: He proved that yellow fever is transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, a landmark in tropical medicine.
  • 2-c. Edward Jenner – Smallpox vaccination: Introduced cowpox inoculation as a preventive method against smallpox, laying the foundation of modern immunization.
  • 3-a. James Lind – Prevention of scurvy by citrus fruits: Conducted the first clinical trial in sailors, showing that citrus fruits prevented scurvy.
  • 4-d. Ronald Ross – Malaria caused by Anopheles: Discovered the role of Anopheles mosquitoes in the transmission of malaria, winning the Nobel Prize.

choices.text: Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR
Check carotid pulse, Start CPR, call for help and activate ERS, Defibrillate
Defibrillate, assess response, check carotid pulse, Maintain airway
Start CPR, Activate ERS, Defibrillate, Check pulse

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for CPR in Basic life support?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR

 

The American Heart Association (AHA) provides guidelines for BLS as part of its Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) recommendations. Here are the core steps of BLS as per the latest AHA guidelines :

 

1. Scene Safety: Before you start, ensure that the scene is safe for both the patient and the rescuer.

 

2. Check Responsiveness: Gently tap the patient and shout, "Are you okay?" to determine if the patient is responsive.

 

3. Activate the Emergency Response System: If the person is unresponsive, call for help or have someone else call emergency services (like 911 in the U.S.) and get an automated external defibrillator (AED) if available.

 

4. Check Breathing and Pulse Simultaneously: Look for normal breathing while checking for a pulse. If the person isn't breathing or is only gasping and has no pulse, begin CPR.

 

5. CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation):

 

  • Compressions: Start with chest compressions. Place the heel of one hand on the center of the chest and the other hand on top, interlocking the fingers. Compress the chest hard and fast, at a depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm) for adults, at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute. Allow complete chest recoil after each compression.

  • Airway: After every 30 compressions, open the airway using a head-tilt-chin-lift maneuver.

  • Breathing: Give 2 rescue breaths after 30 compressions. Make sure there's a good seal with the patient's mouth and give a breath over one second that makes the chest rise visibly. If the chest doesn't rise, reposition the head and try again.

 

6. AED Use: As soon as an AED is available, turn it on and follow its prompts. Apply the pads and allow the AED to analyze the rhythm. If a shockable rhythm is detected, make sure no one is touching the patient and deliver the shock. Immediately resume chest compressions after the shock.

 

7. Continue CPR: Keep going with CPR (30 compressions:2 breaths) until emergency medical help arrives, the person starts to show signs of life (like breathing), the scene becomes unsafe, or the rescuer is too exhausted to continue.

 

Educational Objective : Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR is the correct sequence in Basic life support.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2715-2716

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 1-day history of skin rash. Two weeks ago, she had an episode of recurrent genital lesions, which began with small papules and subsequently became vesicular with ulceration, crusting, and eventual healing. On physical examination, she appears comfortable. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Skin findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythema multiforme

 

Erythema multiforme (EM) is an acute, immune-mediated condition often triggered by infections, most commonly Herpes simplex virus. It presents with target lesions (concentric rings with a central dusky zone), typically involving extremities and sometimes mucosa. Patients are usually stable and afebrile. EM is self-limiting, and management involves treating the underlying cause (e.g., suppressive antiviral therapy for HSV). This patient’s recent genital herpes followed by target lesions is a classic sequence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disseminated herpes simplex infection: Presents with systemic illness, fever, diffuse vesiculopustular lesions, and potential visceral involvement. This patient is stable, afebrile, and has target lesions, not diffuse vesicles.

 

Option C. Primary HIV infection: Manifests with flu-like illness, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a maculopapular rash, not with target lesions linked to recent HSV reactivation.

 

Option D. Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS): A severe mucocutaneous reaction often triggered by drugs, with fever, systemic symptoms, and widespread epidermal necrosis. Unlike EM, SJS has extensive mucosal involvement and systemic toxicity.

choices.text: Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the results of a study comparing two antihypertensive drugs in an Indian population. She comes across the term "p-value" in her statistical analyses. Which of the following best describes the interpretation of a p-value with regard to the probability related to the null hypothesis? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true

 

  • The p-value represents the likelihood of mistakenly rejecting a true null hypothesis. It serves as the threshold for determining statistical significance.
  • In essence, the p-value signifies the probability of erroneously rejecting a valid null hypothesis, leading to a Type I error.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true: This describes a correct decision where the null hypothesis is true, and the researcher correctly decides not to reject it. This scenario does not involve a p-value interpretation.

 

Option C. Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false: This describes a Type II error, where the null hypothesis is false, but the researcher fails to reject it. The p-value is not directly related to this scenario.

 

Option D. Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false: This describes a correct decision where the null hypothesis is false, and the researcher correctly rejects it. This is the goal of hypothesis testing but not the specific interpretation of a p-value.

 

Null Hypothesis

 

  • Hypothesis (H): Is an assumption about the status of a phenomenon
  • Null Hypothesis (H0): In Biostatistics, when we have to prove a particular hypothesis about difference between 2 regimens, we make Null Hypothesis (For examples, If we have to prove that new treatment is better than older treatment, H0 = new treatment is not better than older treatment).

questions.text: Which of the following LA would not need dose readjustment in a case of liver failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Procaine

 

  • Procaine is an ester-type local anaesthetic.
    • Metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase, not the liver.
    • Safe in hepatic impairment, no dose adjustment needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Lidocaine: Amide-type; metabolized in liver → reduce dose in liver failure.

 

Options C. Bupivacaine: Amide-type; metabolized in liver → dose adjustment required.

 

Options D. Ropivacaine: Amide-type; hepatic metabolism → adjust dose in liver disease.

 

 

NOTE: Amides have an extra “i” in their spelling.

questions.text:
Which of these is the definition of effective CPR?

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20 - 24 breaths per minute.
  2. Chest compressions: 100-120/min.
  3. Allow complete chest recoil.
  4. 2-2.4 inches depression.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3 and 4

 

  • Chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute (point 2)
  • Allowing complete chest recoil after each compression (point 3)
  • Compression depth of 2 to 2.4 inches (5 to 6 cm) for adults (point 4)
  • Push Hard, Push fast.

 

Respiratory rate of 20-24 breaths per minute (point 1) is not a standard component of effective CPR. Instead, the recommended ventilation rate during CPR is lower, i.e., 10-12/minute (e.g., 2 breaths after every 30 compressions for adult CPR).

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological findings is characteristic of acute eczema?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Intercellular edema

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive investigations provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography 

 

Dobutamine stress echocardiography (DSE) evaluates myocardial ischemia and contractile reserve under pharmacologic stress. It provides both diagnostic and prognostic information, helping to stratify the risk of perioperative cardiac events in patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery. DSE is especially useful in patients who cannot perform exercise testing due to limited mobility or comorbidities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exercise ECG testing: Useful for detecting ischemia in patients able to perform exercise, but limited sensitivity and specificity, and less accurate in predicting perioperative outcomes.

 

Option C. Myocardial perfusion scintigraphy: Provides perfusion imaging and risk assessment, but is more expensive, less readily available, and may overestimate risk in certain populations.

 

Option D. Coronary angiography: Gold standard for anatomic coronary assessment, but it is invasive, not routinely performed purely for preoperative risk stratification, and does not provide functional information about perioperative risk.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the OPD due to skin lesions on his back. He first noted the spots 5 years ago and says they are becoming more numerous. The lesions are occasionally pruritic but are otherwise asymptomatic. Medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seborrehic keratosis

 

The likely diagnosis is A. Seborrheic keratosis. The image shows multiple, well-circumscribed, waxy, stuck-on, hyperpigmented papules and plaques, which are characteristic of seborrheic keratoses. Seborrheic keratoses are benign skin lesions that often appear in older adults and increase in number over time; they may be pruritic but are otherwise asymptomatic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actinic keratosis: presents as rough, scaly plaques on sun-exposed areas and is considered premalignant, not as "stuck-on" warty lesions.

 

 

Option C. Pityriasis versicolor: presents as hypo- or hyperpigmented patches with fine scale.

 

 

Option D. Acanthosis nigricans: shows velvety, hyperpigmented thickening of flexural surfaces, not discrete raised plaques

questions.solution: Ans. C) 14

questions.text: In a busy OPD at a District hospital, you are evaluating a 5-year-old boy who presents with fever, generalized malaise, and a distinctive rash. The child's clinical presentation strongly suggests a diagnosis of measles. The mother, anxious about the contagious nature of the disease and the risk it poses to her other kids and family members, inquires about the recommended period of isolation for her infected child. What would be your most appropriate recommendation for the duration of isolation?
questions.solution: Ans. D) From catarrhal stage to 4 days after rash

choices.text: Koilocytosis of the superficial epidermal layers

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the OPD with a 4-day history of severe left-sided chest discomfort. The pain is constant and has a burning quality. Over the last day, the patient has developed a rash in the area of discomfort. He has not had similar symptoms before. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be found in the affected area?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ﻿﻿﻿Multinucleated cells with intranuclear inclusions

 

The clinical scenario is classic for Herpes Zoster (shingles) caused by reactivation of latent Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) in dorsal root ganglia. Patients first experience burning neuropathic pain in a dermatomal distribution, followed by the appearance of grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. On histopathology, VZV produces multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions (Cowdry type A bodies). A Tzanck smear from the base of the vesicle can reveal these cells. This cytopathic effect is shared with HSV, but the clinical presentation here strongly supports shingles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acantholysis and intercellular IgG deposits:

 

  • This describes pemphigus vulgaris, an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by antibodies against desmoglein.
  • Histology shows loss of intercellular connections (acantholysis) and a “fish-net” pattern of IgG on immunofluorescence.
  • Not related to a dermatomal painful rash.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions: 

 

  • These are typical of poxyvirus infections, e.g., molluscum contagiosum, where large intracytoplasmic inclusions (Henderson–Patterson bodies) are seen.
  • Lesions appear as umbilicated papules, not painful grouped vesicles.

 

Option C. Koilocytosis of the superficial epidermal layers: 

 

  • Koilocytes are squamous epithelial cells with perinuclear halos and nuclear atypia seen in HPV infections (e.g., verruca vulgaris, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia).
  • HPV causes warts, not painful dermatomal vesicular eruptions.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient is brought into the casualty with maxillofacial trauma following a road traffic accident (RTA). He is unconscious with a GCS of 7/15 and his SpO2 is dropping with absent breath sounds on right side. JVP is raised. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricothyrodotomy

 

This patient has severe maxillofacial trauma, making conventional oral or nasal intubation impossible. With a GCS of 7, definitive airway protection is mandatory. Cricothyrotomy provides a rapid surgical airway when standard intubation is not feasible. It is lifesaving in emergency trauma airway management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bag and mask ventilation: Not adequate in maxillofacial trauma because airway obstruction is likely, and it does not secure a definitive airway in an unconscious patient with low GCS.

 

Option C. Needle thoracostomy: The patient does have features of tension pneumothorax (absent breath sounds, raised JVP, hypoxia), but the airway must be secured first. Oxygenation will not improve without a patent airway.

 

Option D. Nasotracheal intubation: Contraindicated in maxillofacial trauma as it can worsen airway compromise, cause bleeding, and risk intracranial passage if base of skull fracture exists.

questions.text:
Which of the provided options align with the depicted equivalence margin graph? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

 

  1. ‘A’ represents superiority of new treatment
  2. ‘I’ represents Inferiority of new treatment
  3. ‘E’ represents Non-inferior treatment
  4. ‘C’ is inconclusive
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2 and 3 

 

There are three types of comparators in Randomised Control Trials:

 

1. Superiority Trial – New drug is Better than old drug

 

2. Non-Inferiority Trial – New drug as good as old drug

 

3. Equivalence – New drug same as old drug

 

 

Other Option:

 

4. 'C' is inconclusive: This statement is incorrect as per the image. 'C' represents a superior treatment, as it falls well into the "new treatment better" region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In equivalence margin graphs for RCTs, 'A' can indicate a superior treatment, 'I' an inferior treatment, and 'E' a non-inferior treatment. 'C' does not represent an inconclusive result; it represents superiority.

He has been breastfeeding every 2-3 hours and voiding frequently. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

Mode = median, not equal to mean

Given the graphical representation, which of the following correctly represents the relationship among the mean, median, and mode for the data presented?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Mean = median, not equal to mode

questions.text: Which health program in India would provide financial aid to BPL families to help manage a child with major life-threatening diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rashtriya Arogya Nidhi

 

Provides financial assistance for medical treatment of poor patients with life-threatening diseases, especially children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pradhan Mantri Swasthya Suraksha Yojana: This scheme was launched to reduce regional imbalances in tertiary healthcare services by setting up AIIMS-like institutions and upgrading medical colleges. It does not provide direct financial support to patients.

 

Option C. Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: This is a training program for healthcare workers, focusing on essential newborn care and resuscitation. It aims at reducing neonatal mortality, not financial assistance.

 

Option D. Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram: A child health screening and early intervention service, addressing 4Ds—

 

  1. Defects at birth, 
  2. Deficiencies,
  3. Diseases, and 
  4. Developmental delays including disabilities. It provides screening and referral, not direct treatment funding.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient has grade III ASA. Which of the following post bronchodilator PFT findings requires further evaluation of the lung function of the patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

  1. Hall-Wellner Band can be employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meir analysis 
  2. Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) Program covers Schizophrenia, OCD, Mental illness in children and depression. 
  3. According to WHO, the safe limit of radioactivity in drinking water is Beta activity 1 Bq /L and Alpha activity 2 Bq/L. 
  4. Surveillance is the performance and analysis of routine measurements while monitoring is the continuous analysis of systematically collected data.
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1 only

questions.text: A 4-week-old boy is brought to the OPD for his first well-child visit. He has been exclusively breast-fed since birth and has had normal urine and stool output. The patient takes supplemental vitamin D and no other medications. His 4-year-old brother has neurofibromatosis but is otherwise healthy. There is a 5-cm skin lesion with overlying hair on the upper back, as shown below. The remainder of the skin examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Congenital melanocytic nevus

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements?

 

  1. Rabies is an example of amphixenosis 
  2. A disease whose pathogenic response is higher in children compared in adults is defined as hyperendemic disease
  3. Most efficient to control urban malaria is environmental control of larva
  4. CBR ≈ (8×TFR) + 1
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4

 

  • Environmental (larval) control — source reduction, filling, drainage, larviciding — is highly effective in urban malaria where breeding sites are identifiable and man-made. 
  • The rule-of-thumb relation CBR ≈ (8 × TFR) + 1 is a demographic approximation often used in population studies. 

 

Therefore statements 3 and 4 are correct in public health contexts.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Rabies is an example of amphixenosis: Rabies is classically a zoonosis (animal-to-human transmission). The term amphixenosis is uncommon and not correctly applied here; hence statement 1 is not correct.

 

2. A disease whose pathogenic response is higher in children compared in adults is defined as hyperendemic disease: Hyperendemic denotes persistently high incidence across age groups; the wording “pathogenic response higher in children” is inaccurate — that describes age-specific susceptibility rather than the definition of hyperendemic.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a facial lesion as shown in the image below. On examination, the lesions are painful & the edges are well demarcated & raised. Ear is also showing similar erythematous lesions. This infection is most likely to be caused by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Group A streptococcus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Group B streptococcus: Group B streptococcus (GBS) primarily causes infections in newborns and pregnant women but is an uncommon cause of skin infections in healthy adults. When it does cause skin and soft tissue infections, it is usually in immunocompromised patients or those with diabetes., although it rarely might present with classical erysipelas-like lesions.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus commonly causes skin infections such as boils, abscesses, and cellulitis but usually has indistinct borders and may produce pus. It is generally responsible for cellulitis.

 

Option D. Hemophilus influenzae type b: Hemophilus influenzae type b commonly causes respiratory tract infections, meningitis, and epiglottitis, especially in children.

questions.text: All of the following are health care delivery indicators, except
questions.solution: Ans. C) Bed turnover ratio

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman who is on SSRI for major depression for 6 months underwent hernia surgery. Post-operatively the nurse administered an analgesic for the pain. After some time, the patient developed fever, rigidity, restlessness, and delirium. Clonus is demonstrated on examination. Which of the following is unlikely to have caused her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Buprenorphine 

 

  • The patient shows classic signs of serotonin syndrome:
    • Mental status changes: delirium, restlessness
    • Autonomic dysfunction: fever
    • Neuromuscular abnormalities: rigidity, clonus
  • Serotonin syndrome can occur when drugs that increase serotonergic activity are given to patients on SSRIs.
  • Buprenorphine: Partial μ-opioid agonist and κ-opioid antagonist with minimal serotonergic activity; therefore, unlikely to cause serotonin syndrome. Clinical relevance: Safe for analgesia in patients on SSRIs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meperidine: Mechanism Strong serotonin reuptake inhibitor in addition to μ-opioid agonism. Clinical significance: Can precipitate serotonin syndrome in patients on SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, or other serotonergic drugs.

 

Option C. Tramadol: Mechanism μ-opioid agonist plus inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake. Clinical significance: Common trigger for serotonin syndrome in patients on SSRIs.

 

Option D. Fentanyl: Mechanism: Potent μ-opioid agonist, minor serotonergic activity reported. Clinical significance: Associated with serotonin syndrome; less likely than meperidine or tramadol.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

  1. Role of Social factors in Disease causation is studied under Social Pathology
  2. Birth of a baby should be registered within 21 days 
  3. Birth dose of BCG is 0.05ml intra-dermal 
  4. >0.01 IU/ml tetanus antitoxin in the blood is considered clinically protective against tetanus
questions.solution: Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

questions.text: An 8-year-old previously healthy girl is brought to the OPD by her mother due to hair loss on the scalp. Several weeks ago, the mother noticed the patch of hair loss, which has progressively enlarged. The mother also says that the girl frequently scratches at the area. The child recently changed to a different school and has been anxious about new teachers and friends. Skin examination findings are shown in the image below. There are several enlarged, tender, occipital and posterior auricular lymph nodes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Dermatophyte infection

questions.text: A study on 100 urban women evaluates potential risk factors for breast cancer using RR and 95% confidence intervals (CI). How many protective factors show a statistically significant association with breast cancer?
questions.solution: Ans. A) 3

choices.text: Duration can be prolonged using an inlaying catheter

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of epidural over spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Duration can be prolonged using an inlaying catheter

questions.text:
A team of epidemiologists is planning to conduct a survey on the prevalence of malnutrition in a village. What is the correct sequence of steps involved in the planning of this activity?

 

  1. Establishment of objectives and goals
  2. Fixing priorities
  3. Analysis of the health situation
  4. Assessment of resources
questions.solution: Ans. A) 3, 1, 4, 2

choices.text: Chlorine which appears after the break point has been reached
Chlorine required to oxidize all organic matter and destroy the bacteria
Chlorine which prevents subsequent microbial contamination during storage
Chlorine amount that allows sustainable residual chlorine for 6 months

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the chlorine demand of water?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Chlorine required to oxidize all organic matter and destroy the bacteria

questions.text: A child came for DPT vaccination at 10 weeks with a past history of fever more than 40° C and inconsolable cry at 6 weeks following vaccination. What should be done next?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Give DTaP vaccine

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most commonly used cranial nerve for monitoring the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

 

The setup shown in the image is used for neuromuscular monitoring in anaesthesia, which typically uses nerve stimulators to assess the degree of muscle relaxation (paralysis) during and after surgeries requiring muscle relaxants. Here the image shows Ulnar nerve monitoring using Adductor Pollicis muscle. 

 

Most commonly used cranial nerve for monitoring:

 

The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is the most commonly used cranial nerve for neuromuscular monitoring in this context, especially when monitoring the orbicularis oculi or corrugator supercilii muscles for facial nerve stimulation.

 

Facial nerve monitoring provides information about the onset and adequacy of neuromuscular blockade, which is critical for timing of intubation and ensuring proper muscle relaxation during certain surgical procedures.

choices.text: One dose of Td + tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient presents with a contaminated wound on his right leg following a road traffic accident. He has received complete tetanus immunization, and the last dose was 7 years ago. Which of the following should be done in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) One dose of Td

questions.text: A researcher is comparing three different groups with non-normally distributed data and small sample sizes. Which of the following tests is best suited for analyzing this non-parametric data?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Friedman test

questions.text: Which of the following is a secondary skin lesion?
questions.solution: Ans. A)

questions.text: All of the following anti-retroviral drugs are given orally except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ibalizumab

 

Ibalizumab is a monoclonal antibody given IV, not orally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Efavirenz: NNRTI, oral.

 

Option C. Fostemsavir: Oral gp120 attachment inhibitor.

 

Option D. Abacavir: NRTI, oral.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. FORD foundation is aiding in building toilets in India 
  2. Normalcy of data can be measured by histogram, box-whisker plot and Shapiro-Wilk test 
  3. Haddon matrix is a tool for prevention of injuries using epidemiology. 
  4. The Reston ebolavirus is most pathogenic in humans.
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is caused by herpes simplex virus?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Whitlow

choices.text: Undiagnosed muscular dystrophy and muscular weakness
Muscular weakness due to fasciculation produced by succinylcholine

questions.text: A 70 kg elderly athlete undergoes surgery and is administered succinylcholine due to the unavailability of vecuronium. A total of 640 mg of succinylcholine is given intermittently. During recovery, the patient is unable to breathe spontaneously or move limbs. What is the explanation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phase 2 blockade produced by succinylcholine

 

  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker.
  • When high doses(2-10mg/kg) or repeated doses are given (as in this case: 640 mg), the neuromuscular junction may transition from phase 1 (depolarizing) to phase 2 (desensitizing) blockade.
  • Phase 2 blockade mimics non-depolarizing blockade: the patient becomes flaccid and cannot move or breathe, and response to reversal agents is different.
  • Unlike phase 1, neostigmine may reverse phase 2 blockade only partially or paradoxically worsen it, so careful monitoring is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudocholinesterase deficiency increasing action of succinylcholine: Causes prolonged action of normal doses of succinylcholine, but the dose here is supramaximal, making phase 2 blockade more likely.

 

Option C. Undiagnosed muscular dystrophy and muscular weakness: Would predispose to hyperkalemia or increased sensitivity, but acute flaccid paralysis after high-dose succinylcholine points to phase 2 blockade.

 

Option D. Muscular weakness due to fasciculation produced by succinylcholine: Fasciculations are transient muscle twitches, not prolonged paralysis which would cause muscular weakness.

 

TOF and types of Blocks:

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a nonhealing ulcer on the left upper extremity. For the last 2 months, he has had an enlarging ulcerated lesion, with intermittent bleeding and itching. In the last 3 weeks, the patient has also noted local numbness, paraesthesia, and burning pain. He does not recall any injury prior to the onset of symptoms.  The patient has a history of renal transplantation and takes an appropriate immunosuppressive regimen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

  1. Relieving pressure of pop off valve in AMBU bag is 30-40 mm Hg
  2. Morphine should be avoided in day care surgery. 
  3. Ketamine is the iv anaesthetic agent of choice for severe asthma 
  4. Propofol is anti-emetic and anti-pruritic
questions.solution: Ans. D) 2, 3, 4

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to skin lesions on her trunk and proximal upper limbs. The patient noticed the lesions after returning from a summer vacation at a Goa beach a week ago. During the vacation, she had sun exposure on several occasions without prior application of sunscreen. The lesions are mildly itchy but not painful. Medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malassezia globosa infection

 

  • The image shows hypopigmented, scaly macules and patches on the trunk, commonly seen after sun exposure.
  • This is classic for Tinea versicolor (Pityriasis versicolor), caused by the lipophilic yeast Malassezia globosa (previously M. furfur).
  • Lesions are hypopigmented or hyperpigmented due to fungal interference with melanin production.
  • Mild itching may be present, especially after sweating or heat exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune melanocyte injury:

 

  • Refers to vitiligo.
  • Produces depigmented (chalk-white), well-demarcated macules, not scaly patches.
  • Vitiligo is non-pruritic and progressive, not linked to sun/heat exposure.

 

 

Option B. Dermatophyte skin infection:

 

  • Dermatophytes (Trichophyton, Microsporum, Epidermophyton) cause ringworm (tinea corporis).
  • Lesions are annular, erythematous, scaly patches with central clearing, not hypopigmented diffuse patches like in this case.

 

 

Option D. Ultraviolet skin damage:

 

  • Sunburn causes erythema, pain, blistering.
  • Chronic UV exposure causes photoaging and actinic keratoses, not multiple hypopigmented macules.

choices.text: Removing the husk of the dal
Soaking the dal in limewater overnight and then boiling
Limiting the amount of dal to a quarter of the total cereals and pulses consumed per day

questions.text: All of the following can prevent the contamination caused by this pulse except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Removing the husk of the dal

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about hospice care? 

 

  1. Disease is the centre of concern 
  2. The patient is sovereign 
  3. Death should neither be prolonged nor hastened 
  4. The aim is to improve the quality of life 
  5. The intention is to cure 
  6. Done when expected survival is <6months
questions.solution: Ans. A) B, C, D, F

choices.text: Testing for anemia using a digital hemoglobinometer

questions.text: 6 interventions in Anemia Mukt Bharat includes all except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Biennial deworming

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery, and the anesthesia team needs to ensure the proper connection of the oxygen supply. Which of the following PIN (Pin-Index) configurations corresponds to the oxygen supply in medical gas cylinders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 

 

 

The Pin-Index Safety System (PISS) is designed to prevent wrong gas cylinder connections in medical gas systems.

 

For oxygen cylinders, the correct pin-index configuration is pins 2 and 5. This unique combination ensures that only an oxygen cylinder fits on the oxygen yoke, preventing accidental cross-connection with other gases.

 

Other common configurations include:

 

Nitrous oxide: pins 3 and 5

 

Medical air: pins 1 and 5

 

Entonox: pin 7 (single pin)

 

CO2 : pins 1 and 6 if concentration of CO2 is >7% 

 

CO2 : 2 and 6 if concentration of CO2 is <7%

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Glycopyrrolate is used as an anxiolytic before anesthesia. 
  2. Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is the most common cause for hospital admission after day care surgery.
  3. The best type of anesthesia for pre-eclampsia is Epidural anesthesia
  4. Propofol is known to cause maximum pain on injection.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4

 

2. Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is the most common cause for hospital admission after day care surgery: True. PONV is a significant cause of delayed discharge or unplanned admission in ambulatory surgery patients.

 

3. The best type of anesthesia for pre-eclampsia is Epidural anesthesia: True. Epidural anesthesia is preferred as it avoids the hypertensive response associated with general anesthesia and provides good analgesia and hemodynamic stability.

 

4. Propofol is known to cause maximum pain on injection: True. Propofol often causes burning or pain at the injection site, making it a recognized side effect.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

1. Glycopyrrolate is used as an anxiolytic before anesthesia: False. Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic primarily used to reduce secretions and prevent bradycardia, but it is not used for anxiolysis.

questions.text: In the Motivation model of health education, there are 3 stages of adoption of new ideas. What is the third one other than awareness & motivation?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Action

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of chronic acne. Over the last 6 months, the patient has tried several over-the-counter acne treatments without improvement. She has a history of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder and mild intellectual disability. Her mother has a seizure disorder, and her maternal grandmother died of kidney failure. Vital signs are within normal limits. Facial examination findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberous sclerosis

 

The most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition is tuberous sclerosis.

 

The image shows numerous red papules clustered on the nose and cheeks, consistent with facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum). In the clinical scenario, the patient has chronic treatment-resistant facial "acne," a history of mild intellectual disability, and a family history of seizures and renal disease—all classic for tuberous sclerosis complex. Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in TSC1 or TSC2, leading to hamartomas in multiple organs, including the skin (angiofibromas), brain (seizures, intellectual disability), and kidneys (angiomyolipomas, cysts, renal failure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fabry disease: Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by alpha-galactosidase A deficiency leading to globo-triaosyl-ceramide accumulation. It presents with angiokeratomas—small, dark red to black papules—typically involving the lower trunk, groin, and upper thighs. Systemic involvement includes neuropathic pain, kidney failure, and cardiac abnormalities.

 

Option B. Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1): NF1 is a genetic disorder characterized by café-au-lait macules, cutaneous and plexiform neurofibromas, axillary/inguinal freckling, and Lisch nodules of the iris. It does not cause acneiform or angiofibroma-like facial lesions. Learning disabilities and skeletal abnormalities can be associated.

 

Option D. Von Hippel-Lindau Disease: Von Hippel-Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant cancer syndrome with hemangioblastomas of the retina and central nervous system, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas. It primarily presents with tumor-related symptoms.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the frequency of polycythemia in a population of a remote, mountainous region. A representative sample of 100 men shows a normal distribution of hemoglobin concentration with a mean concentration of 17g/dl and a standard error of 0.1 g/dl.  Which of the following best represents the probability that a subject will have a hemoglobin concentration greater than 18 g/dL?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 16%

 

The mean is 17 g/dL, SE = 0.1. A value of 18 g/dL is 10 standard errors above the mean (1 g/dL ÷ 0.1). From normal distribution, a difference of 1 g/dL corresponds to a z-score of 10. However, the question is framed for SD context (commonly tested): 1 SD above the mean corresponds to ~16% probability in the tail, hence 16% is correct.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Tinea capitis - Orange fluorescence

questions.text:
All of the following are true except: 

  1. TBA, ANM, AWW are grassroot, village level workers. 
  2. Crowd is a group of people with a common leader 
  3. Reference woman weighs 55kg 
  4. STEPS approach for WHO includes Behavioral, physical and psychological measurements
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1, 2, 4

choices.text: Defibrillate using monophasic defibrillator at 360 joules
Defibrillate using biphasic defibrillator at 360 joules

questions.text: You are the team leader during a cardiac arrest resuscitation scenario in a hospital setting. A 65-year-old patient has suddenly collapsed and is unresponsive. The monitor displays a rhythm as shown in the image. What is the next immediate step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Defibrillate using monophasic defibrillator at 360 joules

 

The rhythm in the image is ventricular fibrillation—a shockable rhythm in cardiac arrest. For monophasic defibrillators, the recommended dose is 360 joules for each shock. Thus, the next immediate step is defibrillation with a monophasic defibrillator at 360J 

 

This action provides the highest chance for successful conversion of VF to a perfusing rhythm and is in line with current ACLS guidelines

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administering epinephrine: Epinephrine is given after initial defibrillation attempts and ongoing CPR cycles if VF persists

 

Option B. Starting high-quality CPR: If a defibrillator is not immediately available, begin CPR immediately while preparing for defibrillation.

 

Option D. Defibrillate using biphasic defibrillator at 360 joules: Biphasic devices deliver lower energy (typically 120-200 J initial) with improved efficacy and less myocardial injury compared to monophasic. This is preferred when biphasic defibrillators are available over monophasic.

choices.text: Rideal-Walker Coefficient (RWC) is used to represent the germicidal power of a disinfectant.
For workrooms with exposure to contaminants, the minimum recommended number of air changes per hour is 4-6 to maintain air quality and protect worker health.
Demographic trap is seen in Stage 2 of demographic cycle.
Nodal Ministry for Disaster Management is ministry of Health and Family Welfare

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nodal Ministry for Disaster Management is ministry of Health and Family Welfare

 

This statement is incorrect because the nodal authority for disaster management in India is the Ministry of Home Affairs (through NDMA/SDMA structures). Health ministry plays a crucial response role (medical relief, public health) but is not the central nodal ministry for overall disaster management coordination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rideal-Walker Coefficient (RWC) is used to represent the germicidal power of a disinfectant: Historically, Ridel-Walker/phenol coefficients were used to compare germicidal efficacy under specified conditions; although dated, the statement about its use is essentially correct in principle.

 

Option B. For workrooms with exposure to contaminants, the minimum recommended number of air changes per hour is 4-6 to maintain air quality and protect worker health: For general workrooms with low-to-moderate contaminant levels, a guideline of ~4–6 air changes/hour is commonly recommended to maintain acceptable air quality and dilution ventilation.

 

Option C. Demographic trap is seen in Stage 2 of demographic cycle: The demographic trap (rapid population growth due to falling mortality while fertility remains high) corresponds to the transitional stages (commonly Stage 2), so statement C is acceptable.

questions.text: What does phase II represent in the below image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Expiration of mixed air

 

Phase II in the given capnography image represents the expiration of mixed air—a combination of dead space air (no CO₂) and alveolar air (CO₂-rich). This phase is seen as the rapid upstroke on the capnogram, transitioning from the baseline (dead space) to the alveolar plateau as alveolar gas mixes with exhaled air.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Inspiration: The waveform phase that represents inspiration is the flat baseline segment following the downward slope after the alveolar plateau, commonly referred to as phase 0 or the inspiratory phase on a capnogram.

 

Option B. Expiration of dead space air: This actually represents phase I, where the gas exhaled is mostly from anatomic dead space with negligible to no CO₂. Phase II follows transition from dead space to alveolar air.

 

Option D. Expiration of alveolar air: This corresponds to phase III, the alveolar plateau phase, not phase II.

questions.text: What is AMBU aura 40?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First generation supraglottic airway device

 

  • AMBU Aura 40 is a first-generation supraglottic airway device (SAD).It is named because it can be re used upto 40times.

 

 

  • First-generation SADs:
    • Provide a simple airway seal over the laryngeal inlet.
    • Do not have a gastric drainage tube.
    • Used for routine airway management in elective surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Second generation supraglottic airway device: Have gastric access, higher seal pressures, and improved safety. Examples include LMA ProSeal or AMBU AuraGain

 

Option C & D. Third generation supraglottic airway device: & Fourth generation supraglottic airway device: Feature advanced designs for higher seal, intubation compatibility, or integrated monitoring. Eg- Video Laryngeal Mask (VLMTM)

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with a great toe infection. She had a significant discoloration with a subungual hyperkeratosis that caused surface changes. She was suspected of having onychomycosis. Which is the topical drug given in toenail onychomycosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tavaborole

 

Onychomycosis is a fungal infection of the nails, commonly caused by dermatophytes (e.g., Trichophyton rubrum), and presents with nail discoloration, subungual hyperkeratosis, and nail plate deformity. Tavaborole is a topical antifungal agent (oxaborole class) that inhibits fungal protein synthesis by blocking leucyl-tRNA synthetase. It is FDA-approved for topical treatment of toenail onychomycosis and is applied daily for 48 weeks. Tavaborole is particularly useful for mild to moderate cases or when systemic therapy is contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole: An oral triazole antifungal used in the treatment of systemic mycoses and onychomycosis. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis. Oral itraconazole is effective for toenail disease and is used in pulse or continuous regimens.

 

Option C. Griseofulvin: An older oral antifungal that inhibits fungal mitosis by disrupting microtubule function. It was historically used for dermatophyte infections of skin, hair, and nails but is now largely replaced by terbinafine and itraconazole due to lower efficacy and longer treatment duration. Not given topically for nails.

 

Option D. Caspofungin: An echinocandin antifungal that inhibits β-glucan synthesis in the fungal cell wall. It is used intravenously for serious systemic infections such as invasive candidiasis and aspergillosis.

questions.text: What is the most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)

 

 

  • Mapleson Circuit Type A[Magill’s] is most effective for Spontaneous Ventilation.
  • For spontaneous breathing, the efficiency of Mapleson circuits (from most to least effective) is: A > D > C > B
  • Efficiency Order for Controlled Ventilation (from best → worst) :D > B > C > A

 

Explanation of Circuits - (Mapleson Classification):

 

  • Type A (Magill’s circuit / Mapleson A):
    • Most efficient for spontaneous breathing (least fresh gas flow required).
    • Requires only ~70 mL/kg/min fresh gas flow.
    • Commonly used in adults.
    • Lac’s circuit is Co-axial modification of Magill’s Circuit.
  • Type B & C:
    • Rarely used.
    • Less efficient both for controlled and spontaneous ventilation.
  • Type D (Bain’s circuit – coaxial modification):
    • Most efficient for controlled ventilation, but not ideal for spontaneous breathing.
  • Type E (Ayre’s T-piece):
    • Used in pediatrics, no valves, minimal dead space.
    • Inefficient in adults due to high fresh gas requirement.
  • Type F (Jackson-Rees modification of T-piece):
    • Mostly pediatric use; allows scavenging of gases.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair
questions.solution: Ans. A) World TB day - 28 March

questions.text: Match the following scale types with their lesions?
questions.solution: Ans. A. 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a
